name: Poison Dart Frog
fact: One golden poison dart frog has enough toxin to kill 10 grown men!
question: Why are poison dart frogs so brightly colored?

name: Axolotl
fact: Axolotls can regenerate entire limbs, parts of their brain, and even their heart!
question: Where are axolotls originally from?

name: Red-Eyed Tree Frog
fact: Red-eyed tree frogs flash their bright red eyes to startle predators - it's called 'startle coloration'.
question: When are red-eyed tree frogs most active?

name: Fire Salamander
fact: Fire salamanders got their name because people thought they were born from flames when they crawled out of logs thrown on fires.
question: How do fire salamanders defend themselves?
options: They secrete poison from their skin
answer: They secrete poison from their skin

name: American Bullfrog
fact: Bullfrogs can eat almost anything that fits in their mouth, including birds and mice!
question: Why is it called a bullfrog?
options: It's as big as a bull
Its call sounds like a bull
answer: Its call sounds like a bull

name: Eastern Newt
fact: Eastern newts go through a unique 'red eft' stage where they live on land for 2-3 years before returning to water.
question: What is the difference between newts and salamanders?
options: Newts spend more time in water
answer: Newts spend more time in water

name: Cane Toad
fact: Cane toads are one of the most invasive species in the world and can poison animals that try to eat them.
question: How do cane toads produce their poison?

name: Glass Frog
fact: Glass frogs have transparent skin on their belly - you can see their heart beating!
question: Why do scientists think glass frogs are transparent?

name: Goliath Frog
fact: Goliath frogs are the largest frogs in the world, growing up to 12.5 inches long and weighing 7 pounds!
question: Where do Goliath frogs live?

name: Caecilian
fact: Caecilians are legless amphibians that look like worms or snakes and live underground.
question: What sense do caecilians rely on most?

name: Mudpuppy
fact: Mudpuppies keep their feathery external gills their entire lives - they never fully grow up!
question: What is special about mudpuppies compared to most salamanders?

name: Surinam Toad
fact: Female Surinam toads carry their eggs embedded in the skin of their back until babies pop out!
question: What shape is a Surinam toad's body?

name: Hellbender
fact: Hellbenders are the largest salamanders in North America, growing up to 2 feet long!
question: What nickname do hellbenders have due to their wrinkly skin?

name: Japanese Giant Salamander
fact: Japanese giant salamanders can live over 50 years and grow up to 5 feet long!
question: What do Japanese giant salamanders mainly eat?

name: Tomato Frog
fact: When threatened, tomato frogs puff up their body and secrete a sticky white substance that can cause allergic reactions.
question: Why is it called a tomato frog?

name: Spring Peeper
fact: Spring peepers are tiny frogs whose loud chorus is one of the first signs of spring!
question: How big is an adult spring peeper?

name: Alpine Newt
fact: Male alpine newts develop bright blue coloring and an impressive crest during mating season.
question: Where do alpine newts prefer to live?

name: Olm
fact: Olms are blind cave salamanders that can survive up to 10 years without food!
question: What color are olms?
